_meta.unique_mechanic: First contract: choose to enter the Authority web
_meta.narrative_premise:
In Fenmire, an Authority clerk has filed the world under the wrong heading. The error is not paper-deep: it changes who is permitted to grieve, who is permitted to eat, and who is permitted to be remembered.

The Domain of Ink calls it a vellum. The people call it ledger. You call it vellum.

A bell rings without sound. A ledger turns a page by itself. Someone you have never met has filed your name under ‘solvent’.

You decide whether to accept that lie or make it expensive.
_meta.player_motivation: Shape Authority, gain leverage, and keep your humanity.
branching_outcomes: Advance a Domain score and unlock seals
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: setbacks increase Censure and shift later dialog tone; progress remains possible.

_meta.narrative_premise:
In Blightlands, an Authority clerk has filed the world under the wrong heading. The error is not paper-deep: it changes who is permitted to grieve, who is permitted to eat, and who is permitted to be remembered.

The Domain of Ink calls it a margins. The people call it ash-ink. You call it margins.

A messenger offers you a contract written in ink.
It promises clarity. It hides rewriting.

If you sign, you become easier to categorize — and harder to erase.

_meta.narrative_premise:
In Blightlands, an Authority clerk has filed the world under the wrong heading. The error is not paper-deep: it changes who is permitted to grieve, who is permitted to eat, and who is permitted to be remembered.

The Domain of Witness calls it a footprints. The people call it glass. You call it footprints.

A small rule in Witness has become a large harm.

The Authority will call it procedure. The hungry will call it weather. You must call it something you can live with.
_meta.player_motivation: Shape Authority, gain leverage, and keep your humanity.

The Domain of Witness calls it a glass. The people call it footprints. You call it glass.

A seal is not a reward. It is a verdict in your favor, stamped onto your skin.

You can take it — and become legible to the Ladder forever.
_meta.player_motivation: Shape Authority, gain leverage, and keep your humanity.

_meta.narrative_premise:
In Fenmire, an Authority clerk has filed the world under the wrong heading. The error is not paper-deep: it changes who is permitted to grieve, who is permitted to eat, and who is permitted to be remembered.

The Domain of Ink calls it a vellum. The people call it ledger. You call it vellum.

The contract wants a signature. The world wants a person.
_meta.player_motivation: Shape Authority, gain leverage, and keep your humanity.

_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: setbacks increase Censure and shift later dialog tone; progress remains possible.

_meta.narrative_premise:
The Northern Wastes do not threaten you. They simply refuse to care.

A scout’s warning is practical, not kind. The monastery’s lamps glow when no one tends them. Your breath turns sideways in a tunnel that should be still.
_meta.player_motivation: Secure safe passage and learn what the cold is hiding.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you lose time and resources, but keep momentum.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Footprints appear where no one walked. Then they turn around without turning.

Someone is practicing being a traveler.
_meta.player_motivation: Learn what is hunting the roads before it learns your name.
branching_outcomes: Gain leverage over a local threat
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the threat escalates; you still proceed.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Skyreach keeps records of vows so the sky remembers what it promised.

Now the entries are rewriting themselves in weather.
_meta.player_motivation: Stop the vows from becoming a weapon.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the vow warps; you gain a scar instead of a seal.

_meta.narrative_premise:
In the ice caverns, your breath drifts sideways as if it is being pulled.

A delver swears the tunnels are changing because something inside them wants warmth.
_meta.player_motivation: Find what is feeding and decide whether to starve it or bargain.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you lose supplies; the route remains open.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A mountain guide laughs at your confidence. Not because you cannot climb—because the pass can.

To cross, you pay with boots, bones, or oaths.
_meta.player_motivation: Secure passage without handing over something you cannot replace.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you pay extra later.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A warden of flame calls the caldera a court. Heat is the law. Ash is the witness.

It demands an Ember Core that still remembers what it burned.
_meta.player_motivation: Win passage through the caldera without becoming fuel.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you take damage/resources; progress continues.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A cartographer draws what stays still—mostly regrets.

Their compass spins only when you think of home.
_meta.player_motivation: Decide whether a map is help, trap, or bargain.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you lose time; the route shifts.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A mirror oracle claims shards show truths and whole mirrors show bargains.

The choice is not moral. It is expensive.
_meta.player_motivation: Leave the Mirror Wastes with your name intact.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you gain a lasting flag/censure.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A sentinel warns: the Umbral Reaches accept entry. They do not accept return.

The void eats hesitation first.
_meta.player_motivation: Choose whether to enter, and what you are willing to lose.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you are marked; you continue.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Lira does not promise kindness. She promises clarity.

If she walks beside you, spirits will tell the truth that hurts most.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Lira and accept the price of painful truth.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Lira leaves; you can try again later.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A spirit points to the place you avoid thinking about.

Lira asks you to look anyway.
_meta.player_motivation: Prove you can carry truth without breaking.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you take a scar; the chain continues.

_meta.narrative_premise:
The most important thing a spirit says is the thing it cannot say out loud.

Lira teaches you to hear what is missing.
_meta.player_motivation: Learn to listen without inventing answers.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you misread the silence; you continue.

name: Lira: A Name for the Hunted

_meta.narrative_premise:
Some threats are protected by being unnamed.

Lira offers a name that will make the thing turn its head.
_meta.player_motivation: Name the threat and accept being noticed.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you are marked; you proceed.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Lira asks for one honest admission. Not confession—inventory.

What truth do you carry that you never spend?
_meta.player_motivation: Finish Lira’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: loyalty gain is smaller; chain ends.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Korinth does not follow. He accompanies—when it serves the balance.

To earn his help, you must bring proof the winds are being bribed.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Korinth by proving discipline over impulse.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Korinth refuses for now; you can return later.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Korinth claims the wind is being bribed—paid to carry certain whispers farther than they should travel.

He asks you to find the proof without chasing every rumor like a dog after thrown bones.
_meta.player_motivation: Earn Korinth’s respect by proving restraint and focus.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you bring imperfect proof; Korinth sharpens your method and sends you again.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Korinth teaches a rhythm meant to keep fear from steering your hands.

Four breaths, one strike—repeat until the body believes it.
_meta.player_motivation: Learn Korinth’s method to withstand the wastes’ pressure.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the lesson is bruising but usable; your next encounter carries the mark of it.

name: Korinth: A Straight Line Is Not a Cage

_meta.narrative_premise:
A traveler begs you to bend the rules ‘just once.’ Korinth watches to see if your discipline is cruelty or clarity.

The wind listens too.
_meta.player_motivation: Define what your restraint is for.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Korinth calls it out; the lesson becomes harder, not impossible.

name: Korinth: Balance Paid in Small Coins

_meta.narrative_premise:
The one paying the wind offers you the same bargain: a shortcut.

Korinth’s lesson is simple—balance is not a vow, it is a bill. You choose how to pay it.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Korinth’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the wind’s payer escapes, but Korinth commits to your path anyway.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Mirka reads walls the way priests read scripture.

In Eldhollow, she finds a stone that should not remember—yet it does, holding a record of pressure and fracture like a secret diary.

She offers her craft, but only if you agree to treat the world’s breaks as problems to solve, not omens to worship.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Mirka by proving you can choose practical repair over superstition.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Mirka refuses for now; you can return later with clearer intent.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Mirka insists the first step is not heroism. It is measurement.

A break in the stonework is widening—slowly, patiently—like a mouth learning how to speak.

You must decide which facts belong on the ledger, and which temptations belong in the fire.
_meta.player_motivation: Help Mirka define the problem before the problem defines you.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: your numbers are off; Mirka corrects them with sharp words and sharper chalk.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A wall fails where it is asked to carry more than it was promised.

Mirka suspects the town is leaning on something it never agreed to hold—an invisible burden paid forward in silence.

You track the true load: not stone, not timber, but obligation.
_meta.player_motivation: Uncover what is really stressing Eldhollow’s foundations.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you misplace the blame; the structure still holds—barely—long enough for another attempt.

name: Mirka: Break Only What Must Break

_meta.narrative_premise:
Sometimes you cannot patch. You must cut away rot so the rest can live.

Mirka’s rule: break only what must break.

You choose whether to strike cleanly, or strike wildly and call it courage.
_meta.player_motivation: Prove you can apply force with restraint.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: collateral damage hardens Mirka’s tone; the next step becomes more costly, not blocked.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Mirka mixes mortar by habit, but today she measures each handful like it matters.

‘Stone holds because it is honest,’ she says. ‘Mortar holds because it keeps its promise.’

You decide what promise you will keep when the next wall starts to fail.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Mirka’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the structure holds, but your promise is smaller; Mirka stays, watching what you do next.

name: Edrin: The Mark That Won’t Wash

_meta.narrative_premise:
Edrin’s curse is not a chain you can see. It is a mark that makes certain things find him—again and again.

In the Vale of Bones, he asks you to help him set terms with the thing that keeps returning.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Edrin by agreeing to fight smart, not loud.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Edrin refuses for now; you can return later.

name: Edrin: A Trail Made of Names

_meta.narrative_premise:
Edrin tracks by what people refuse to say.

You follow a trail made of names—spoken, struck out, and swallowed.

Somewhere ahead, the curse is learning new routes.
_meta.player_motivation: Help Edrin convert fear into usable clues.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the trail goes cold; Edrin teaches you how to warm it again.

name: Edrin: The Arrow You Don’t Loose

_meta.narrative_premise:
Edrin says some shots can’t be taken—not because you can’t hit, but because hitting teaches the wrong lesson.

The curse wants you reckless. You decide whether to oblige.
_meta.player_motivation: Practice restraint under pressure.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you act too fast; Edrin adapts the plan rather than ending it.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Edrin insists the curse is not just a predator—it is a fisher.

It casts hooks into habits.

You set a counter-hook and decide what you are willing to sacrifice to bury it.
_meta.player_motivation: Turn the curse’s pattern against itself.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the hook slips; you learn the shape of it anyway.

_meta.narrative_premise:
The curse finally answers like a person—too calmly, too precisely.

Edrin does not ask you to kill it. He asks you to set terms it can’t twist.

You decide what you are willing to promise.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Edrin’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the terms are imperfect; Edrin stays anyway, watching what you keep.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Noma keeps an index of what the Hollow City tried to forget.

She offers her mind—if you agree that knowledge is a tool, not a trophy.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Noma by treating truth like responsibility.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Noma refuses for now; you can return later.

name: Noma: The Catalog of Wrong Doors

_meta.narrative_premise:
Some doors are wrong because they lead nowhere. Others are wrong because they lead somewhere that should not exist.

Noma teaches you the difference.
_meta.player_motivation: Help Noma classify a new kind of threat.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: your category is crude; Noma refines it without discarding the work.

_meta.narrative_premise:
A ledger appears with entries written in handwriting that isn’t yours—but the memories feel like they are.

Noma asks what you owe to truth, and what truth owes to you.
_meta.player_motivation: Decide how far you’ll go to keep knowledge.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you choose badly; the city teaches you why, and you continue.

name: Noma: The Shelf That Refused You

_meta.narrative_premise:
A shelf in the Hollow City’s archive refuses your hands as if it can judge intent.

Noma insists you don’t force it. You negotiate—with patience, with proof, or with sacrifice.
_meta.player_motivation: Earn access without becoming what you fear.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the shelf stays shut, but leaves a clue on the floor.

name: Noma: A Rule for Keeping Secrets

_meta.narrative_premise:
Noma asks for one rule—a principle you will follow whenever you hold dangerous knowledge.

Not a slogan. A rule you can keep.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Noma’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: your rule is too soft or too cruel; Noma challenges it but stays.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Rusk’s forge is louder than most arguments, and kinder than some prayers.

He’ll travel with you if you respect what metal remembers: heat, force, and the shape of the hand that wielded it.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Rusk by choosing craft over cruelty.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Rusk refuses for now; you can return later.

name: Rusk: The Blade That Won’t Hold Quiet

_meta.narrative_premise:
A blade comes off the anvil with a vibration that feels like speech.

Rusk says it’s not magic. It’s memory—put in by the wrong hands.

You decide whether to quiet it or listen.
_meta.player_motivation: Help Rusk define what a weapon should be for.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you choose poorly; the steel still works—just with consequences.

name: Rusk: Pay in Heat, Not Blood

_meta.narrative_premise:
Someone wants Rusk to forge for them—and offers payment in suffering disguised as necessity.

Rusk insists: you can pay in heat, effort, and time. If they demand blood, you refuse.
_meta.player_motivation: Choose what you will and won’t trade for power.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the bargain turns; you still walk away with a lesson and a scar.

name: Rusk: Quench in Snow, Quench in Ash

_meta.narrative_premise:
Rusk says power is a hot thing—you choose how to cool it, or it chooses for you.

Snow is restraint. Ash is spite.

You decide what kind of strength you make.
_meta.player_motivation: Prove you can shape force without being shaped by it.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the steel comes out flawed, but usable; the next fight shows you how.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Rusk asks for an oath—not to him, but to the craft: what you will never forge, no matter the reward.

You decide what line you won’t cross when the world begs you to.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Rusk’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: your oath is flimsy; Rusk calls it out and stays to see if you strengthen it.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Rill has ferried too many desperate people to too many bad decisions.

She’ll travel with you if you understand one thing: water doesn’t keep secrets, it moves them.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Rill by choosing a route that doesn’t drown someone else.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Rill refuses for now; you can return later.

name: Rill: A Boat Is a Promise

_meta.narrative_premise:
Rill says every crossing is a promise: you will arrive with everyone you brought.

You decide which risks are acceptable, and which are just cowardice with math.
_meta.player_motivation: Learn to weigh danger without becoming numb.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the route goes wrong; you still learn why.

name: Rill: The Price of a Quiet Ferry

_meta.narrative_premise:
Someone offers Rill a bribe: carry them quietly, no questions.

Rill asks you whether ‘quiet’ is safety… or complicity.
_meta.player_motivation: Decide what you’ll help move through the marsh.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the bribe turns sour; you keep moving.

name: Rill: Oars in Mud, Oars in Blood

_meta.narrative_premise:
The marsh doesn’t care what you meant. It cares what you did.

Rill forces a confrontation where you must choose whether to keep your hands clean, or keep someone alive.
_meta.player_motivation: Prove you can choose under pressure.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: you choose badly; Rill doesn’t abandon you—she makes you face it.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Rill asks you for a rule you will follow on every crossing—every threshold, every bargain, every door.

A rule that keeps you from becoming cargo.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Rill’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: your rule is naive; Rill tests it, then helps you sharpen it.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Sera’s light is not comfort. It is a tool that burns away rot—and sometimes burns what it touches.

In the Blightlands, she asks if you can accept a holy thing that is sharp.
_meta.player_motivation: Recruit Sera by choosing truth over soothing lies.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: Sera refuses for now; you can return later.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Sera says prayer is not asking. It is aligning.

But the Blightlands turn alignment into a weapon.

You decide whether to wield it.
_meta.player_motivation: Help Sera define faith that doesn’t excuse harm.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: your doctrine cuts too deep; you proceed with the scar.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Sera asks for confession—but not for forgiveness. For accuracy.

What did you burn to survive?

What will you burn next?
_meta.player_motivation: Choose honesty that has consequences.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the lie holds for now; the world remembers anyway.

_meta.narrative_premise:
Sera’s light reveals rot, but it also reveals things you wanted to keep hidden.

You decide what should be revealed—and what should be spared.
_meta.player_motivation: Learn to use holy force without becoming careless.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: the light burns too hot; you adapt rather than retreat.

name: Sera: The Mercy You Can Afford

_meta.narrative_premise:
Sera asks a cruelly practical question: mercy costs something.

Who will pay it this time?

You decide what mercy you can afford—and what you refuse to buy with someone else’s suffering.
_meta.player_motivation: Close Sera’s opening arc and deepen trust.
_meta.failure_states: Fail-forward: mercy is imperfect; Sera stays to see what you do next.
